rename.from: TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' when calling train_network()
rename.to: "TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' " when calling train_network()

body:
Could you post the full error? (also upgrade to 2.0.4.1 :) thanks! 

As an aside, you can always just copy the full folder to the server, you just have to change the project_path in the config file. Then running create.. on server as you did will take care of conversions that might need to be done to path names (one can label on Windows or Unix) :)

Ah, thanks for the input, I will try just uploading the entire thing. Here is all the output:
```

Looks like the config_pose file of the model has been found? - perhaps try to create it on the server again (for another shuffle) and check?
closing as we have answered but OP has not responded; please feel free to let us know if the solution worked!

seemingly the same error as before.

Did I botch it up in how I uploaded or do you think it is some error due to running it on this server? I know others have managed to train a DLC network on these servers so I assume I messed up the project somehow.
The error says: “Cannot open: Permission denied” the weights are not downloaded. Please click on wiki (top of page) for the troubleshooting tips on how to download them manually.

rename.from: "TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' " when calling train_network()
rename.to: Weights not doqnloaded. Permission denied. "TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' " when calling train_network()

rename.from: Weights not doqnloaded. Permission denied. "TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' " when calling train_network()
rename.to: Weights not downloaded. Permission denied. Then training throws errors "TypeError: can't set attributes of built-in/extension type 'object' " when calling train_network()

body:
Hi, HPC2N support here, the cluster the reporter is running on.

The core problem here is that DeepLabCut hard-assumes that it can write to the install location of the package. As the software is centrally installed into part of the parallel file system which users do not have write permissions to, no user-initiated automatic or manual download scheme will be successful.

https://github.com/AlexEMG/DeepLabCut/blob/v2.0.4/deeplabcut/generate_training_dataset/trainingsetmanipulation.py#L434-L439

The mentioned "other people" were running pip-installed in a virtualenv they created, so they had write permissions. The version the reporter is using is built completely from source in our module system with all dependencies from scratch.

We're probably going to patch this on our site to put the location of ResNet downloads somewhere in the project path or into the part of the user's home directory that is writable by compute nodes.

Optimally it would be nice if either the location was configurable in some way or if DLC was aware of this kind of scenario and put the files into the best reasonable place that was writable by the user. The same problem kind of also manifests if you ever intend to get DLC packaged by an OS distribution.

As far as possible we kind of want to avoid putting datasets in the software tree as they tend to have a different release cadence and size than the software.

Hi there. This is why we recommend using Docker containers on servers, and how many large servers run software (ie AWS). We supply a fully installed container here: https://github.com/MMathisLab/Docker4DeepLabCut2.0

For a traditional department server, that's a fine solution where you can trust end-users with what's effectively root access.

In our case, it's a shared academic HPC cluster with compute nodes behind a batch system, which typically provide software built against optimized dependencies in a central module tree. Our motivation for this is that we can often gain a fair bit of performance by tuning installations for the particular hardware they should run on.

Unfortunately we cannot let end users run Docker-type containers as the central Docker daemon would not be governed by per-user job constraints. At best we have rootless Singularity containers which can launch some types of images if lucky.

I wonder, does this image also contain the ResNet weights out of the box or would one still need to have enough writable rights inside the container or bind-mount a writable location from the outside to be able to fetch them?

Do you know if there is any other part of DLC that expects write rights to the install tree, or is it limited to obtaining the ResNet weights?

Fair enough! There are also some Singularity containers for DLC that janelia uses, but in short, only part is ResNet weights (once). Could make that a variable to pass a path to downland elsewhere (and be sure to point to the path); if useful feel free to make a PR :)

@AlexEMG @MMathisLab  This error doesn't seem to arise because of the problem in downloading the initial weights. Rather the error seems to be thrown while trying to open and read the config file in the train directory (train.py). I had trained the network on HPC2N last week, however this week, while trying on another project it gave the above result. By comparing the pose_cfg.yaml files in the two project folders, it seems that the latest one has a difference in the **field 'all_joints_names'**. Instead of just a list of the joint names, the new pose_cfg.yaml has the following form:
```
all_joints_names: !!python/object/new:ruamel.yaml.comments.CommentedSeq
  listitems: [w1p1, w1p2, w1p3, w1p4, w1p5]
  state:
    _yaml_format: !!python/object/new:ruamel.yaml.comments.Format
      state: !!python/tuple
      - null
      - {_flow_style: false}
    _yaml_line_col: !!python/object:ruamel.yaml.comments.LineCol
      col: 0
      data:
        0: [13, 2]
        1: [14, 2]
        2: [15, 2]
        3: [16, 2]
        4: [17, 2]
      line: 13

```
When I manually changed the form to just the list, it throws no error, and the training process is initiated. However I would like to know what is the reason for the change in this yaml file and if there is some solution to this.
Regarding the download of weights, downloading it manually and changing the path for initial weights in pose_cfg.yaml file works on HPC2N.

Confirming Athiras comment, after manually copying resnets to folder, changing config_yaml to point to that folder and in config_yaml changing:

`all_joints_names: !!python/object/new:ruamel.yaml.comments.CommentedSeq
  listitems: [leftEar, righEar, neck, tailBase, tailMid, tailPoint]
  state:
    _yaml_format: !!python/object/new:ruamel.yaml.comments.Format
      state: !!python/tuple
      - null
      - {_flow_style: false}
    _yaml_line_col: !!python/object:ruamel.yaml.comments.LineCol
      col: 0
      data:
        0: [17, 2]
        1: [18, 2]
        2: [19, 2]
        3: [20, 2]
        4: [21, 2]
        5: [22, 2]
      line: 17`

to just
`all_joints_names: [leftEar, righEar, neck, tailBase, tailMid, tailPoint]`

training can be intialized!
@jonthu please also update your dlc version (as for some combination of project age/ dlc version it can create those ruamel.yaml objects (rather than the simple list of bodyparts).

ok so I am not the only one with the weights download issue, I suspected permission was denied because I don't have root access to the server. It doesn't work even in the supplied docker container and I get the exact same error.
Any patches coming up or do we have to manually download the weights?

hi @waseemabbas05 how do you have rights to install deeplabcut on the server? Also, please remember we are a research lab and provide this code and help for free, so we'd appreciate a bit of patience ;). If you want to work on a patch, or test this one, #280  feel free.

Hi
No I don't have the rights to install deeplabcut on the server, so I am using a docker
I understand you might have too much at your hands, I would love to contribute :)
if I am able to come up with a patch, I will let you know
At this moment, I have downloaded the initial weights manually and edited the pose_config file to circumvent the problem
